text: got the old red on hi everyone Anthony
Fantan oh here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new war on
drugs album lost in the dream
Philadelphia rock band the war on drugs
this is their third full-length LP
following up what was pretty much their
breakout album back in 2011 slave
ambient an LP that I did not love but
did appreciate for its puncher tracks
like come to the city as well as it's
pretty novel mix of genres like
psychedelic rock folk rock krautrock
Americana and the singer-songwriter
stylings of artists like Tom Petty or
Bruce Springsteen in a nutshell this
record to me was kind of like combining
the music of Noy with Bob Dylan I
thought the combination was a great idea
I thought these sounds were really
trippy as well as vivid I thought there
were some great songs on this record but
all too often I found the tracks on here
sort of getting distracted and lost in
the very haze that made this record such
a unique piece of music in the first
place and as a result of that the band
sort of was losing track of interesting
songwriting and and was just sort of
making music that was a bit too comatose
for me and considering ex band member
Kurt Vile left the group a little while
ago to sort of improve upon the sound in
his own records I think in a lot of ways
he's kind of beat them at their own game
with this more psychedelic approach to
Americana folk rock singer-songwriter
music so I really wasn't sure what to
expect from the war on drugs on this
latest LP but still I ended up coming
out of this thing pleasantly surprised
yes the band does tend to wear their
influences on their sleeves there are
some occasionally uninteresting moments
on this thing too but I still think lost
in the dream is a noticeable improvement
upon what the band has been doing up
until this point the production is far
more lush more colorful more layered a
bit more saxophone seems to make its way
into this sea of delayed panoramic
guitars and the band also continues to
deliver fast
ethereal rockers barnburners with fiery
guitar solos and really tight drumming
tracks like red eyes and an ocean
between the waves two of my favorites on
this entire LP really explosive moments
on this record that I like a lot but
some of the more toned-down songs on
this new LP from the war on drugs
specifically the song disappearing sort
of has me feeling like I'm listening to
an extended version of the Miami Vice
theme song just a really lackluster
eighty style new wave slow jam however
the very blatant New Wave influence that
the war on drugs showcases isn't always
a bad thing for one I think these
aesthetics are embraced and executed
really tastefully on the song burning
which immediately as the track hits it
feels like I'm listening to a new order
song and not just sort of in the way
that they're oh they're emulating it but
it hits me with the same rush of emotion
and power that a great new order song
does except of course there is a
completely different vocal delivery to
the whole thing its tracks like this
that actually make me wish that the
current set of bands out there that are
writing such hazy blissful music
actually went this very tasteful route
the music here is joyous it's feel-good
it's intoxicating and yet the
instrumentation is lively you can
actually hear things going on it feels
like I'm listening to a band of people
who are engaged with the music that
they're actually playing they're not
about to go to sleep I feel like I'm
listening to a revision of Bruce
Springsteen's dancing in the dark with a
fog machine blasting at it from every
single direction and like maybe some
laser lights or something and while I'm
not always totally in love with what
frontman Adam grandis seal is is doing
with his vocals I can't really deny that
what the war on drugs does with the
momentum of their tracks the colors the
effects the layering the progression of
their songs it's all pretty enthralling
for the most part like with the opener
under the pressure which starts off with
just a guitar some drums vocals kind of
feels like I could be listening to a Tom
Petty and the Heartbreakers track it's
passable it gets a little drab after a
while but in the second third of the
song
synthesizers some horns come in the
drums really start to pick up and that's
when the track really starts to become
just Who I am really starting to fall
for it to become seductive it becomes
enveloping with all these sounds that
it's presenting it's like an ocean a
wonderful ocean of wonderful sexiness
and in the last third of this song there
is a pretty relaxing buzzing ambient
outro that's a very nice on the ears
it's a decent start to the record what
actually ends up captivating me the most
on this LP though are the slower more
straightforward ballads and this is
actually a spot where I feel that the
war on drugs separates themselves
significantly from Kurt Vile they step
past the reverb a little bit deliver
some very vivid detailed passionate
lyrics that have sort of a sense of
place like eyes to the wind I love the
court pression on this track the vocal
melody is nice as well the pedal steel
in the background nice touch and the
closing song in Reverse which starts off
with these really icy tones some vocals
it's very spacious that's very open vast
it's icy as well I would say listening
to the song is like just glass
shimmering with sunlight just gleaming
through it and as the song moves along
the instrumentation really picks up
keeps things engaging from front to back
it's a strong close and to a lesser
extent
I do enjoy the ballad suffering on here
it does get a little too hazy for me at
some spots and a little too drawn-out
but it is one of the prettier tracks on
this LP as well especially with the very
beautiful expressive guitar solo in the
second half of this track and outside of
that there aren't a whole lot of other
songs to address on the cell P other
major highlights and that's because
there are just 10 songs on this record
however it takes up more than an hour of
runtime because the war on drugs does
not hit you with a ton of songs they hit
you with songs they have a ton of length
and on this record much more than their
last record I think they're doing a
better job of justifying these lengths
of songs that run almost nine minutes or
eight or seven because a lot of the time
while there are some pretty simple
straightforward verses and choruses on
these tracks the band really takes their
time
building them up jamming leaving space
in between them there's not a lot of
urgency to move from point A to point B
on these tracks the band sort of takes
it at their own pace and I don't really
mind them waiting and sort of letting
the tension build to shift from one area
of a song to another since the
instrumentation the performances on
these tracks typically are so tight and
nicely put together again the vocals
aren't the most enthralling in the world
and I do think there are a few tracks on
here that run pretty mundane but the
songs are definitely of a higher quality
on here
the hard-hitting and fast-paced tracks
are fantastic overall it sounds like the
band really did a much better job of
adding detail into their music on this
thing and it really feels like they they
fussed over the material on this thing
longer I'm feeling a strong seven to a
light eight on this thing transition if
you've given this record a listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and that's about it
Anthony Fantana music review forever
